title: Esther Becomes Queen
shortSummary: This chapter details the selection of Esther as queen after Vashti's removal, highlighting God's providential care through Mordecai's guardianship and Esther's favor with the king. It also introduces a plot against King Ahasuerus that Mordecai uncovers, setting the stage for future deliverance.
timeline: c. 5th century BC - Persian Empire under King Ahasuerus (Xerxes I)

keyCharacters.name: Esther
keyCharacters.description: A Jewish orphan raised by Mordecai who is chosen to be queen for King Ahasuerus, demonstrating grace and favor.

keyCharacters.name: Mordecai
keyCharacters.description: A Jew living in Shushan who raises Esther as his own daughter and plays a key role in protecting the king.

keyCharacters.name: King Ahasuerus
keyCharacters.description: The Persian king who removes Vashti and selects Esther as his new queen.

keyCharacters.name: Hegai
keyCharacters.description: The king's chamberlain in charge of the women, who favors Esther and provides for her needs.

keyCharacters.name: Bigthan and Teresh
keyCharacters.description: Two of the king’s chamberlains who conspire to assassinate King Ahasuerus but are discovered by Mordecai.

definitions.definition: A ceremonial cleansing process involving oil of myrrh and sweet odors, lasting twelve months, preparing the women for presentation to the king.
An official in charge of managing the king’s household, including the women in the palace.
A member of the tribe of Benjamin, one of the twelve tribes of Israel, to which Mordecai belonged.
The exile of the Jewish people to Babylon, during which Mordecai’s family was taken from Jerusalem.

outline.heading: The King's Decree and Search for a New Queen
outline.description: After Vashti's removal, King Ahasuerus commands a search for beautiful young virgins to replace her as queen, demonstrating the king’s authority and the beginning of Esther’s story.

outline.heading: Mordecai and Esther’s Background
outline.description: Introduction of Mordecai, a Jew in exile, and Esther, his orphaned cousin whom he raises as his daughter, highlighting God’s providence in preserving His people.

outline.heading: Esther’s Favor and Preparation
outline.description: Esther is brought to the king’s palace, gains favor with Hegai and the king, and is ultimately crowned queen, illustrating God’s sovereign hand in her rise.

outline.heading: Mordecai’s Loyalty and the Conspiracy Against the King
outline.description: Mordecai uncovers a plot by two chamberlains to assassinate the king, reports it through Esther, and the conspirators are executed, showing Mordecai’s faithfulness and God’s protection over the king.

application: Trust in God's providence even when circumstances seem uncertain, as He works behind the scenes for His purposes.
Obedience to godly counsel, like Esther’s submission to Mordecai’s instructions, leads to blessing and favor.
Be faithful in small responsibilities, as Mordecai’s vigilance protected the king and positioned him for greater influence.
Seek God’s favor through humility and integrity rather than self-promotion.

keyVerses.text: And the king loved Esther above all the women, and she obtained grace and favour in his sight more than all the virgins; so that he set the royal crown upon her head, and made her queen instead of Vashti.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's favor resting on Esther, marking her divine appointment as queen and the turning point in God's plan for His people.

keyVerses.text: Esther had not yet shewed her kindred nor her people; as Mordecai had charged her: for Esther did the commandment of Mordecai, like as when she was brought up with him.
keyVerses.significance: Esther’s obedience to Mordecai’s command demonstrates faithfulness and trust, crucial for God’s plan to unfold.

keyVerses.text: And when inquisition was made of the matter, it was found out; therefore they were both hanged on a tree: and it was written in the book of the chronicles before the king.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the reward of faithfulness and the preservation of the king’s life, which is vital for the unfolding story of deliverance.
